summary.text_en: RÃ¶ntgen accidentally discovered X-rays! These mysterious rays penetrate human body, making bones clearly visible. He took first X-ray photograph in human history - his wife's hand bones. This discovery revolutionized medical diagnosis, earning him first Nobel Prize in Physics.
key_points_en: Won first Nobel Prize in Physics

story.text_en: Evening of November 8, 1895, 50-year-old RÃ¶ntgen researching cathode rays in lab. He covered vacuum tube with black paper, suddenly noticed fluorescent screen meters away glowing! He turned off power, light disappeared; turned on again, light reappeared. He realized he'd discovered unknown rays, calling them 'X-rays' (X for unknown). December 22, he had wife place hand on photographic plate, taking that famous hand bone photo. Wife seeing her skeleton exclaimed: 'I have seen my death!'

fun_facts.text_en: He used 'X' because in mathematics X represents unknown variable, name still used today.
He refused to patent X-rays, believing scientific discoveries should belong to all humanity.
Wife's hand bone photo clearly showed her wedding ring, becoming one of most famous photos in science history.
He donated entire Nobel Prize money to University of WÃ¼rzburg.

experiment.description_en: December 22, 1895, RÃ¶ntgen had wife Anna place hand on box with photographic plate, then exposed to X-rays for 15 minutes. After developing, photo clearly showed hand bones and wedding ring, but flesh invisible! First time in human history seeing internal structure without cutting body open. This photo spread worldwide within weeks, causing sensation.
experiment.why_en: X-rays high energy, penetrate soft tissue (flesh), but absorbed by high-density materials (bones, metal), leaving shadows on film.

simple_explanation.text_en: Imagine X-rays as super powerful flashlight. Normal light shines on your hand, hand is opaque. But X-rays so strong, penetrate your skin and flesh like they're transparent glass! But bones hard and dense, X-rays can't pass through, leaving shadows on photo. So on X-ray film, bones are white, flesh invisible.

impact.text_en: X-ray discovery one of most important breakthroughs in medical history! It let doctors see inside body without surgery, revolutionizing disease diagnosis. RÃ¶ntgen won first Nobel Prize in Physics in 1901. Today, X-ray technology evolved into CT, security screening, material testing and countless applications, saving millions of lives annually.

influenced.contribution_en: Researched radioactive elements radium and polonium

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: RÃ¶ntgen using Crookes' cathode ray tube for experiments, accidentally discovered X-rays. This discovery inspired Becquerel to study fluorescent materials, accidentally discovering radioactivity. Curies further researched, discovering radium and polonium. In 1970s, Hounsfield and Cormack invented CT scanning based on X-ray principles, winning Nobel Prize.

quiz.question_en: Why are bones white on X-ray film while flesh invisible?
quiz.explanation_en: Bones high density, block X-rays, leaving white shadows on film. Soft tissue (flesh) low density, X-rays penetrate, so nearly invisible on film. This density difference creates X-ray film contrast, letting doctors see skeletal structure.
